thread.title: Coxwell Sherpa hits four-year high at Red Ruby Devons autumn show and sale

author: Athwenna Irons
title: Coxwell Sherpa hits four-year high at Red Ruby Devons autumn show and sale
text:
Two-year-old Coxwell Sherpa won male and breed champion at the Devon Cattle Breeders Society’s Autumn Show and Sale at Sedgemoor Auction Centre earlier this month (Image: Country Girl Media) Get Daily updates directly to your inbox Subscribe Thank you for subscribing See our privacy notice Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email
A superb two-year-old bull blazed a trail at the Devon Cattle Breeders Society’s Autumn Show and Sale earlier this month, hitting a four-year high when passing through the buzzing auction ring.
Coxwell Sherpa, from the Berners-Allsop Estate based in Oxfordshire, took both the breed championship title and highest price at Sedgemoor Auction Centre in Somerset on Thursday, October 4.
Auctioneers, Greenslade Taylor Hunt, knocked Coxwell Sherpa down at 3,600 guineas – the highest price for a bull sold at the Society’s Autumn Show and Sale since 2014 – to Welsh breeder AJ Jones & Son from Crown Farm in Raglan, Gwent. From left to right: Judge Gavin Hunter with champion bull Coxwell Sherpa, Coxwell herdsman Matt Harris and Helen Davies from sponsors Shearwell Data (Image: Country Girl Media)
He will now join the family’s Crown pedigree herd of Devons, which was established in 2015.
Reserve breed champion went to Dittisham Dimpsey, bred by Sue Fildes from Dartmouth in Devon. He was bought by Gareth Jenkins from Ha’ of Bowermadden, Wick, Caithness for 2,000 guineas. Read More Why these Devon alpaca farmers have transformed their farm to offer luxury holidays for disabled guests
Heywood & Hurd’s in-calf heifer, Whitefield Orange 228th, claimed the title of highest priced female when selling for 1,650 guineas to Steve Cleverdon from Coombe Farm in Hatherleigh, Devon.
Strong maiden heifer, Coxwell Fanciful 43rd, was crowned female champion and sold for 1,150 guineas to new Devon breeder Noel Sharp from Church Stanton, Taunton. Female champion Coxwell Fanciful 43rd (Image: Country Girl Media)
Catherine Broomfield, breed secretary of the Devon Cattle Breeders Society, said after the sale: “The effects of Brexit uncertainty and shortage of forage produced some hard trade with buyers being very selective.
“But they are still prepared to invest in the best cattle forward, encouraged by the breed’s ability to thrive on a very low input diet.” Read More
